awd_titl_txt: MTM 2: Combining structural informatics and crosslinking mass spectrometry to predict the key protein-protein interactions shaping symbiotic microbial communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Microbial communities on and inside of animals play profound roles in biology, affecting the behavior, nutritional status, and resilience of the host. Much of the behavior of microbial communities is driven by interactions between proteins of microbes and the host. These interactions are used by microbes to adhere to, attack, or communicate with other cells in their surroundings. Because microbial communities are tremendously complex, it has proven difficult to determine the set of protein-protein interactions that define and stabilize a community or affect other community members. Understanding the mechanics of those interactions is essential to  engineer or manipulate microbial communities, e.g., by encouraging the presence of beneficial microbes or driving out those that are problematic. This project will unravel the rules governing how protein-protein interactions establish and maintain microbial communities using a combination of bioinformatics and biochemical approaches. The project will target the interaction of two well-known probiotic (‘good’) bacteria with models of the human intestine. The developed methods will also be applicable to a wide range of other microbial communities, both those involving mammals (with applications to agriculture and medicine) and those involving non-living surfaces (with applications to food processing and infrastructure maintenance). Other broader impacts include outreach activities at a museum and training of the next generation scientists in microbiome research.

This project will develop a combination of computational and experimental approaches to determine the identities and functional implications of host-microbe protein-protein interactions (PPIs), in the context of synthetic microbial communities grown on epithelial cell cultures and in human organoids. The studies will focus on colonization by the well-known probiotic strains E. coli Nissle and Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG.  The use of a highly controllable, reductionist system to study the roles of PPIs in the broader behavior of microbial communities will permit the investigators to develop, test, and benchmark experimental and computational tools to identify important PPIs and examine their functional implications. The project will be anchored by the development of advanced computational pipelines to enable large-scale high-quality prediction of the structure and function of PPI networks. In parallel, for the target organoid-microbe communities, the researchers will make use of recently developed crosslinking mass spectrometry methods to experimentally examine the landscape of PPIs in vivo, and transposon library profiling experiments to identify the microbial genes that contribute substantially to host colonization or microbe-microbe competition. This will be followed by the identification of PPIs in multi-species communities using mouse fecal extracts and/or anaerobes that play an important role in the gut microbiome. The research proposed here will contribute to our knowledge base and technical capabilities both through the enumeration of key trans-kingdom protein-protein interactions driving bacterial host colonization (including identification of the interactions that are functionally important), and through the development and refinement of a computational framework for high throughput prediction of inter-organism protein-protein interactions and their functional importance. The methods developed here will be generalizable to permit rapid enumeration of key host-microbe and microbe-microbe PPIs in complex microbial communities.

This project is funded by the Understanding the Rules of Life: Microbiome Theory and Mechanisms Program, administered as part of NSF's Ten Big Ideas and the Division of Emerging Frontiers in the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our NSF-supported research project focused on advancing methodologies for both measuring and predicting protein-protein interactions, which are crucial for understanding biological processes and developing therapeutic interventions, and applying those methods to study host-microbe interactions using the specific driving example of probiotic bacteria interacting with gut enteroids and model tissues. Through this groundbreaking work, we achieved several key outcomes that have enriched the fields of computational biology and proteomics and have broader implications for various scientific disciplines.

 

A major accomplishment was the development and deployment of a chemical crosslinking pipeline for profiling inter-species protein-protein interactions at whole proteome scales. This tool allows us to study complex interactions between proteins from different species, such as E. coli-human and Lactobacillus-human interactions. We also refined a computational post-processing pipeline for crosslinking mass spectrometry (XL-MS), enhancing our ability to verify and analyze these interactions with greater accuracy. While at the beginning of the project we had expected that existing technologies would allow us to quickly accomplish these aims, we found that several unanticipated technical hurdles stood in the way of applying previously existing methods (which had been demonstrated to work well for simple model systems). Through exhaustive optimization of all stages of the procedure, from crosslinking and cell growth methods, to data acquisition, to data analysis, we were able to develop and apply a reliable workflow for obtaining the needed datasets, which will both enhance our understanding of host-microbe interactions in this specific case, and provide a foundation for other similar studies in the future.

Another major set of advances enabled by this project was the introduction of several improved computational pipelines that offer enhanced accuracy over existing methods. These pipelines enable researchers to predict several crucial aspects of the interactions between proteins, including the presence of absence of contacts, the ratios at which proteins interact, and (with more computational power) the exact interaction poses of protein-protein complexes. Our pipelines have proven in community competitions to provide world-leading performance in these areas. Such improvements help expand our understanding of protein interactions, offering best-in-class resources that will benefit researchers around the world.

 

We have also been able to cross-reference AI-driven protein-protein interaction predictions with crosslinking mass spectrometry datasets, in the process highlighting both the strengths and limitations of existing prediction methods, and providing important guidelines for researchers in the field to use in interpreting such predictions.

 

 

Our research has made a meaningful impact on the broader scientific community as well. The results and tools have been shared widely through peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and public-facing web servers, ensuring accessible dissemination of our findings. Additionally, an educational research station, created in collaboration with the University of Michigan Museum of Natural History, disseminates the societal and scientific significance of our work to the general public, fostering greater appreciation and understanding of protein-protein interactions and their role in allowing probiotic bacteria to interact with their hosts.

 

The intellectual merit of our work lies in its advancement of key methodologies in computational biology and proteomics, offering researchers more powerful tools to tackle complex biological questions. The broader impacts are evident as these new methods enhance our ability to model protein-protein interactions, providing critical insights for biology and engineering disciplines.
